title-group.article-title: Testing the Steve Jobs Hypothesis in a B2B Context
title-group.subtitle: Will a Portfolio of Hierarchically Related Technology Products Improve Customer Outcomes?

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Jason Kuruzovich is an assistant professor of Management Information Systems at the Lally School of Management and Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. He has a PhD in information systems from the University of Maryland and studies issues relating to how information technology transforms the world. His research has been published at leading journals including Management Science, Information System Research, the Journal of Marketing, and Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes.

Shu Han is an assistant professor of Management Information Systems at the Sy Syms School of Business, Yeshiva University. Her current research interests include the role of IT in firm innovation and the influence of service expansion on IT product firms. Her works have appeared in Information Systems Research, IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management, Journal of Management Information System, and Small Business Economics.

Nevena T. Koukova is an associate professor of Marketing at the College of Business and Economics, Lehigh University. Her research interests focus on design and marketing of digital information products such as books, newspapers, and movie rentals, and on various aspects of framing on consumer inferences and choice. Her work has been published in Journal of Marketing Research, Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes, Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science, and Journal of Retailing.

T. Ravichandran is the associate dean for Research and a professor in the Lally School of Management and Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. His research has been published in journals such as the Communications of the ACM, Decision Sciences, European Journal of Information Systems, IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management, Information Systems Research, Information Technology and Management, Logistics Information Systems, Journal of Management Information Systems and MIS Quarterly. He currently serves as a department editor of IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management.

abstract.p: This research examines how the type of information technology (IT) provided among hardware, software, and services—and the degree to which the IT provided is bundled into a solution—influences the levels of satisfaction and loyalty of IT buyers. We refer to the hardware, software, and services offerings jointly as the IT products-services stack, as technology stacks are useful visualizations of how layers of technology products are hierarchically related. We utilize over 36,000 ratings of 68 IT vendors provided by the vendors’ customers to test our research model. The findings indicate that vendors offering products in the lower levels of the IT products-services stack experience higher satisfaction and loyalty ratings (hardware > software > services). Moreover, satisfaction and loyalty ratings are highest when hardware, software, and services are provided together—that is, as an IT solution. An important implication of these findings is that IT solutions benefit both vendors and buyers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Information technology (IT) providers often expand into related products and services, exploiting indirect network effects associated with existing customers to facilitate adoption of new products/services (Gao and Iyer 2006) or to gain economies of scope (Helfat and Lieberman 2002). Such diversification into related technology products and services has a positive impact on firm performance (Tanriverdi 2006; Tanriverdi and Lee 2008; Tanriverdi and Venkatraman 2005) and survival (Stern and Henderson 2004). However, Apple’s product suite—perhaps among the most successful examples of diversification into related products and services—was not developed to improve profits or even to ensure firm survival. Rather, Steve Job’s vision of Apple demanded integration of hardware, software, and later services to maintain control over the user experience (Isaacson 2011). This raises the question of whether providing hierarchically related technology products represents a generalizable strategy that can benefit other firms. In other words, are customers of IT firms positively affected when firms expand their offerings to hierarchically related products and services?

This research investigates whether offering a portfolio of hierarchically related technology products and services influences customer satisfaction and loyalty in a business-to-business (B2B) context. Specifically, we examine how the type of IT provided (i.e., hardware, software, and services) and whether the IT products/services are offered together as a solution influences satisfaction and loyalty ratings of IT vendors. Satisfaction (buyer’s evaluative judgment of past purchase and consumption experiences with a vendor; Oliver 1980) and loyalty (buyer’s attitude toward repurchase; Bennett and Rundle-Thiele 2002) are important outcomes for both IT vendors and technology buyers, and as a result it is relevant to understand how vendor offerings may systematically influence these outcomes.

We refer to the vendors’ hardware, software, and services offerings jointly as the IT products-services stack. Technology stacks are useful frameworks to visualize how technology components are hierarchically positioned in layers. Prior work has identified differences between products and services as critical to influencing customer satisfaction and loyalty (e.g., Anderson, Fornell, and Rust 1997; Edvardsson et al. 2000), making this a natural distinction when considering relevant characteristics of IT provided by vendors. We further differentiate between hardware and software because of the fundamental differences in the nature of these products and their delivery. Hardware is a general-purpose technology (Helpman 1998) delivered in the form of a physical product. Software, on the other hand, is an information product that is frequently customized to fit the needs of a specific business process. Solutions—or combinations of hardware, software, and services—involve significant changes in the vendor role and incentives (Kauffman and Tsai 2009; Tuli, Kohli, and Bharadwaj 2007), making it relevant to examine how bundling of layers of the IT stack influences buyer outcomes.

We use an extensive data set of over 36,000 IT vendor ratings given by IT managers and executives in a B2B context over the period 2003–2006 to examine the relationship between the IT product-services stack, satisfaction, and loyalty—analyzing outcomes at the level of the buyer and the IT vendor. Support for the identified relationships at the buyer level links this research to prior findings on drivers of satisfaction and loyalty as evaluated by individuals (e.g., Doll and Torkzadeh 1988; McKinney, Yoon, and Zahedi 2002; Oliver and DeSarbo 1988; Shankar, Smith, and Rangaswamy 2003; Wixom and Todd 2005). Support for the same relationships at the vendor level ties this work to the broader literature examining satisfaction and loyalty at the organizational level (e.g., Anderson, Fornell, and Lehmann 1994; Anderson, Fornell, and Rust 1997; Hogan et al. 2002; Rust and Zahorik 1993). Support for the same relationships across multiple levels—known as multilevel homology—increases confidence in the range of the relationships identified (Chen, Bliese, and Mathieu 2005).

Overall, this research makes several contributions. First, we identify the importance of the type of IT provided in influencing buyer satisfaction and loyalty. Our findings indicate that hardware, software, and services show decreasing (hardware > software > services) satisfaction and loyalty ratings. While past research has identified differences in buyer satisfaction for products and services based on category comparisons (Anderson 1994), this research shows that such distinctions also hold when the products and services are provided by the same company, as is increasingly common for IT product and service providers. Second, we show that buyers obtaining a solution of hardware, software, and services report higher levels of satisfaction and loyalty than buyers obtaining any single layer of the stack. Past research has highlighted the supply-side benefits associated with providing solutions (Tuli, Kohli, and Bharadwaj 2007), finding a positive relationship between vendor performance and related diversification (Tanriverdi 2006; Tanriverdi and Lee 2008; Tanriverdi and Venkatraman 2005). However, to our knowledge this is the first work to empirically examine the role of solutions in influencing the relationship outcomes of satisfaction and loyalty. In addition, the study contributes to the extensive literature on bundling by showing that bundling of hierarchically related IT products and services enhances customer satisfaction and loyalty. Finally, we find that solutions influence the loyalty of customers both through increased satisfaction and directly. This suggests that the increased switching costs associated with the bundling of products and services may provide additional revenue benefits to IT vendors. Together, these findings yield insights into how IT vendor-buyer relationship outcomes are influenced by the nature of the IT provided.

sec.title: Conceptual Framework
sec.p: As shown in the conceptual framework in Figure 1, we characterize vendor offerings separately by the layer of the stack (i.e., hardware, software, and services) and whether IT solutions (i.e., combinations of hardware, software, and services) are provided, arguing that a vendor’s offerings influence the satisfaction and loyalty ratings of its customers.

caption.p: Research framework. (1) IT-related satisfaction relationship such that hardware > software > services; (2) IT solution involves procurement of hardware, software, and services from the same vendor.

sec.p: It is useful to characterize the three IT layers of hardware, software, and services as a stack. The hardware foundation of processing capability and storage is complemented by the software layer—which provides the user interface, manipulates and stores data, and includes the business logic. In the context of an implementation, a third layer of services completes the stack, providing the function of implementing hardware and software in a business process. The stack framework shows how relevant technologies work together in a system to provide functionality to customers—that is, lower layers provide services to upper layers through standard interfaces. Conceptualizing technology through a stack facilitates the communication of the business implications of technology differences. These implications of the technology differences can be measured directly, in the context of a specific buyer relationship, or at the level of the IT vendor. Finally, the stack framework has proved useful in other contexts such as understanding software industry acquisitions (Gao and Iyer 2006), alliances between software firms (Gao and Iyer 2008), and procurement strategies of firms (Kauffman and Tsai 2009).

sec.title: IT Products-Services Stack and Satisfaction
sec.p: The nature of the IT provided in the context of the vendor-buyer relationship is expected to influence the level of satisfaction, such that buyers of lower levels of the stack will have higher levels of satisfaction than buyers of higher levels of the stack (i.e., hardware > software > services). We distinguish between two mechanisms driving uncertainty in the customer experience, one based on differences in information processes and a second based on customer participation.

sec.title: Information Processes
sec.p: As noted, in examining systematic differences in outcomes linked to vendor offerings, past research has identified distinctions between products and services (Parasuraman, Zeithaml, and Berry 1985). Services differ from products in that they are intangible, heterogeneous, simultaneously produced and consumed, and perishable (Rust and Chung 2006). Specifically, services are intangible in that customers cannot examine them directly. They are heterogeneous in that they have greater variability than products, which often can be standardized to provide consistent evaluations. As services are produced at the same time, they are consumed, services cannot be physically inventoried. Finally, because services cannot be physically inventoried, excess capacity cannot be stored and, as a result, services are perishable.

These differences in the characteristics of products and services have been associated with systematic differences in customer satisfaction, with products offering a higher level of satisfaction than services (e.g., Anderson 1994; Fornell and Johnson 1993; Fornell et al. 1996). The primary theoretical mechanisms through which the product/service characteristics influence satisfaction are related to the amount of information available to the purchaser prior to purchase and thus the uncertainty associated with performance. Products can often be extensively inspected prior to purchase, while services can be evaluated only through consumption (Mills 1986). This means that as service vendors have more information about service quality than customers, information asymmetry increases the probability of selecting a poor quality service provider (Mills 1986; Nayyar 1990). More uncertainty associated with the search process can also increase the chance of disconfirmation, where experiences falling short of expectations results in lower levels of satisfaction (Anderson 1973; Oliver 1980). Thus, across industries, satisfaction is lower for services than for products because it is more difficult to evaluate quality before purchase.

Disconfirmation in particular has been used to explain outcomes in a wide variety of IT contexts, including use of websites (McKinney, Yoon, and Zahedi 2002), technology adoption (Bhattacherjee and Premkumar 2004), and satisfaction with application service providers (Susarla, Barua, and Whinston 2003). In complex purchase situations, buyers are more likely to rely on marketer-supplied materials, which often exaggerate the expected performance (Spreng, MacKenzie, and Olshavsky 1996), increasing expectations and thus decreasing satisfaction (Patterson, Johnson, and Spreng 1997). Also, in situations in which there is uncertainty, evaluations of purchase outcomes can be subject to multiple interpretations (Hoch and Deighton 1989), decreasing the resulting vendor ratings (Patterson, Johnson, and Spreng 1997).

Hardware, software, and services exhibit similar distinctions in the level of uncertainty and customization as that between products and services. Hardware is standardized and can be easily inspected by the purchaser, is infrequently customized, and conforms to the general characterization of products used in the marketing literature. Hardware can be characterized by standardized performance criteria that can be evaluated before purchase, including central processing unit speed, storage size, monitor resolution, and so on. In addition, the quality and capability of hardware is dependent on its subsystems (e.g., Intel chips in personal computers [PCs]), which can be evaluated separately from the overall product. As a result, there is a great deal of information on the capabilities and performance of hardware products that can be assessed prior to the purchase.

Software purchases typically have a much higher level of uncertainty, and implementations frequently require the software to be customized. While demonstrations and trial versions of software are often available, the actual working configuration often needs to be matched with the business processes of the organization, customized, and implemented. Thus, software products can be considered more tangible and standardized than services yet more intangible and heterogeneous than hardware products, representing a distinct layer between hardware and services.

IT services represent the highest level of uncertainty, as services are customized to meet the specific context and cannot be demonstrated before purchase. This creates a purchase situation in which the buyer faces a high level of information asymmetry (Nayyar 1990, 1993), increasing the degree of uncertainty. Since promises of cost savings or improved service are frequently made as part of the service relationship but cannot be experienced until after purchase, this increases the chances of disconfirmation and thus is expected to result in lower levels of satisfaction (Caldwell 2002; Hirschheim and Lacity 2000). These findings suggest that information uncertainty will vary with hardware < software < services, and as a result we expect satisfaction to follow the opposite trend.

sec.title: Customer Participation
sec.p: Varying levels of customer participation associated with the delivery of hardware, software, or services are likely to be an additional source of uncertainty. For hardware, its development and production happen before being sold to customers. For software, although the majority of programming is conducted before being sold, it often requires customization and participation from customers. For services, the involvement of customers is even more intense than for software, as buyers are often viewed as coproducers of services.

Past research confirms the necessity of customer participation in influencing quality outcomes of IT implementations (Barki and Hartwick 1994a, 1994b; Hunton and Beeler 1997; McKeen, Guimares, and Wetherbe 1994; Wixom and Watson 2001), and this participation is most extensive at higher levels of the stack. Customer participation during the delivery of hardware, software, and services adds to the differences in buyer outcomes, as the input uncertainty induced by customer participation contributes to the variation in output (Argote 1982). It is difficult for the firm to draw boundaries between the “technical core” and the input-output stages of the production process due to the participation of customers (Parsons 1956). Thus, services are subject to greater input uncertainty than software, which has greater input uncertainty than hardware. As described earlier, higher levels of uncertainty with a technology and customer participation in its implementation result in lower satisfaction levels.
Hypothesis 1a: The type of IT provided will be associated with the satisfaction rating, such that lower levels of the stack will have higher levels of satisfaction (i.e., hardware > software > services).

Similarly, when examining aggregate customer outcomes by vendor, we expect:
Hypothesis 1b: The percentage of customers purchasing hardware, software, and services will be associated with aggregate satisfaction levels of vendors, such that customer relationships involving lower levels of the stack will result in higher levels of satisfaction (i.e., hardware > software > services).

sec.title: IT Solutions and Satisfaction
sec.p: In addition to the absolute layer of the stack, the degree to which the IT vendor bundles hardware, software, and services into a solution will increase satisfaction with the IT vendor. We first review the literature related to solutions, bundling, and the provision of IT solutions. We then present specific mechanisms of influence involving complementarities, improved customer relationships, and simplified procurement that relate vendor offerings to buyer satisfaction.

Many industries have experienced a transition from vendors offering stand-alone products and services to providing solutions—that is, integrated combinations of products and services (Foote et al. 2001; Tuli, Kohli, and Bharadwaj 2007; Wise and Baumgartner 1999). In offering solutions, vendors obtain greater access to information on customer needs (Tuli, Kohli, and Bharadwaj 2007) and often take on additional risk related to the solution outcome when compared with offering traditional products or services (Kauffman and Tsai 2009). Since a solution can be considered a form of bundling, the literature examining bundling is relevant to understanding solutions.

Frameworks for studying bundling have utilized differences in the nature of the bundles for understanding outcomes. Specifically, price bundles (i.e., multiples of the same product) are primarily offered as a method of discounting while product bundles bring integration benefits to customers (Stremersch and Tellis 2002). Past findings suggest that bundling works better for related as opposed to unrelated products (Gaeth et al. 1991; Herrmann, Huber, and Coulter 1997; Sheng, Parker, and Nakamoto 2007) and that consumers may infer savings benefits from bundling even if such savings do not exist (Heeler, Nguyen, and Buff 2007). In addition, customers may be willing to pay higher prices when purchasing a bundle rather than separately purchasing the individual items (Estelami 1999).

IT solutions are a form of product bundling in which related hierarchical components are offered together as a solution. Studies examining incentives for bundling of products and services by IT vendors are in the context of outsourcing and focus on supply-side benefits (Ang and Straub 1998; Lacity and Willcocks 1998; Levina and Ross 2003; Loh and Venkatraman 1992). For example, companies often outsource based on the assumption that the specialized knowledge of IT vendors will both lower costs and improve outcomes (Ang and Straub 1998; Levina and Ross 2003). Although offering related products and services leads to cost saving through sharing of resources, the resulting impact on customer satisfaction or loyalty is still largely unknown. We believe that the benefits that solutions bring to IT buyers can be understood through complementarities, improved customer relationships, and simplified procurement.

sec.title: Complementarities
sec.p: Complementarity is an inherent property of the stack framework and useful for understanding the benefits of bundling of related products (Milgrom and Roberts 1995). In particular, findings indicating the positive influence of bundles of related products on customer outcomes can be understood through the lens of complementarities (Gaeth et al. 1991; Herrmann, Huber, and Coulter 1997; Sheng, Parker, and Nakamoto 2007). In product bundles containing complementary products, the customer is in effect purchasing a system of products that enable and enhance the functionality of each other (Estelami 1999). As Simonin and Ruth (1995) point out, customers may experience greater satisfaction based on economies of time and effort in purchasing and utilizing the bundled items together.

While adjacent stack layers are complementary to each other, a solution can also provide customer benefits resulting from vendors’ improved economies of scope, shared knowledge, and shared resources across different layers (Hill, Hitt, and Hoskisson 1992; Li and Greenwood 2004; Tanriverdi and Venkatraman 2005). For instance, technological knowledge of hardware could be utilized for implementing services, and knowledge of customer needs gained from services could be used in the design of new software or hardware products. Such cross-layer utilization of knowledge provides additional value to customers, likely increasing their level of satisfaction.

sec.title: Customer Relationships
sec.p: While product characteristics are relevant for understanding the difference in customer outcomes, most product purchases are not discrete events, but rely upon embedded relationships between buyers and seller (Dwyer, Schurr, and Oh 1987; Webster and Martocchio 1992). Past research has confirmed that characterizations of relationship quality such as commitment and trust are important in driving relationship outcomes (Johnson, Sohi, and Grewal 2004; Morgan and Hunt 1994; Yang et al. 2008). Relationship interactions such as communication are important in establishing trust and relational commitment (Morgan and Hunt 1994). As such, to the extent that the type of technology provided influences the nature of the interactions between vendors and customers, it is also likely to have a significant influence on the quality of the relationship and the associated level of satisfaction.

Varying levels of customer participation associated with the delivery of solutions is likely to be one of the keys to understanding associated differences in relationship processes and the level of satisfaction. Specifically, a key benefit of offering solutions is the increased opportunity to gain additional relational knowledge—that is, additional knowledge of customer needs—enabling solution providers to enhance customer outcomes through improved fit with customer business processes (Tuli, Kohli, and Bharadwaj 2007). Solution providers are more likely to be able to acquire customer information from multiple touch points, which leads to a holistic view of customer business processes and needs, helping them better satisfy customers and thus increasing satisfaction. This additional information is likely to foster the trust and relationship commitment consistent with positive relationship outcomes (Mohr and Spekman 1994). As a result, we expect solution providers to have high levels of customer satisfaction.

sec.title: Unified Procurement
sec.p: From the IT buyer’s perspective, the interoperability between different stack layers is likely to provide benefits from economies of scope related to consumption (Cottrell and Nault 2004). For example, if a common interface can enable administration of different layers, overall complexity for the customer is reduced. In addition, a solution reduces the coordination typically required for component-based implementations. Kauffman and Tsai (2009) refer to the purchase of a bundle of all related IT stack components from a single vendor as unified procurement. This improved and simplified purchasing experience is likely to result in increased levels of customer satisfaction.

Therefore, because of the complementarities, improved customer relationships, and simplified procurement, we expect:
Hypothesis 2a: Buyer relationships involving solutions (i.e., bundles of hardware, software, and services) will be associated with higher satisfaction ratings.

Similarly, when examining aggregate customer outcomes by vendor, we expect:
Hypothesis 2b: The percentage of customers purchasing solutions (i.e., bundles of hardware, software, and services) will be associated with higher aggregate satisfaction levels of vendors.

sec.title: IT Solutions and Loyalty
sec.p: Research suggests that satisfaction is expected to have a direct influence on customer loyalty, as satisfied customers are more likely to repurchase in the future (Fornell 1992). Satisfied customers are also more likely to generate positive word of mouth, which helps attract potential customers (Blodgett and Anderson 2000). Further, satisfaction results in an increased share of business a customer conducts with a particular service provider (Keiningham, Perkins-Munn, and Evans 2003). Thus, we can expect that both the type of products provided and the degree of bundling will each have corresponding influences on loyalty through their effect on customer satisfaction—that is, satisfaction will mediate the relationship between IT product-services stack and loyalty. This direct relationship between satisfaction and loyalty has been studied extensively by past researchers (e.g., Anderson and Sullivan 1993; Anderson 1994).

In addition to this mediated effect, however, we expect providing solutions to have a direct impact on customer loyalty because of the additional switching costs imposed by solutions. Burnham, Frels, and Mahajan (2003) identified product complexity, breadth of use, and extent of modification as three factors increasing switching costs. Given that solutions can be characterized as more complex, of greater breadth, and more frequently customized than hardware, software, or services individually, solutions will be associated with greater switching costs. In addition, specific buyer expertise is argued to lower switching costs. As vendors employing solutions become very involved in processes of needs assessment (Tuli, Kohli, and Bharadwaj 2007) and risk management (Kauffman and Tsai 2009), companies employing vendor solutions may lose much of the knowledge necessary to enable switching, further increasing the associated costs and thus the resulting loyalty of the customer. Thus, we expect:
Hypothesis 3a: Vendor-buyer relationships involving solutions (i.e., bundles of hardware, software, and services) will be associated with higher loyalty.

Similarly, when examining aggregate customer outcomes by vendor, we expect:
Hypothesis 3b: The percentage of customers purchasing solutions (i.e., bundles of hardware, software, and services) will be associated with higher aggregate loyalty ratings of vendors.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The data were collected as part of a study by a leading information systems management magazine and facilitated by a market research firm yearly for a total of 4 years. The survey questions were created by analysts at the magazine and the market research firm, with the help of feedback from industry professionals. Subscribers to the publication were invited to participate via e-mail. Survey questions were posted on a password-protected website, and respondents were asked to indicate whether they had used or continued to use a list of IT vendors. On average, the list contained 52 vendors and was constructed by a manager each year, incorporating vendors from the Fortune 500 and Global 500 lists, the Forbes Fastest Growing Technology Companies list, the CBR 50 IT Services Vendors list, Hoover’s Online, Baseline magazine’s 50 Fastest Growing Software Companies, Gartner, and annual financial reports of individual companies. Respondents were then asked additional questions about a selection of up to 10 IT vendors with whom they indicated a previous or ongoing relationship.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: The survey asked four questions related to the respondents’ level of satisfaction and one question regarding their loyalty. The original motives for the survey were to provide a practitioner-oriented ranking of vendor quality utilizing the satisfaction of existing customers. As such, measures were created utilizing a practitioner viewpoint of the most important aspects of vendor relationships in a B2B context. Questions related to satisfaction included “meeting commitments to my company on time and budget,” “solving the business problems their products or services were purchased or engaged to solve,” “being flexible and responsive to my company’s needs,” and “meeting my company’s quality expectations for products and services.” Responses ranged from 1 for poor to 4 for excellent. As a measure of loyalty, respondents were asked whether, if they had a choice, they would continue to do business with the vendor through a yes/no (1/0) response. Respondents also indicated the nature of their relationship with the vendor, including whether they have used their hardware products, software products, or consulting services (strategy, outsourcing, internal projects, and telecommunications).

The measures for satisfaction indicated adequate reliability (Cronbach’s α = .881) and were averaged to obtain a value for each vendor-customer relationship. Additional measures provided information regarding the respondent and the respondent’s company, including job title, industry, number of employees, and whether the respondent was a member of the top management team.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: The data spanned the years 2003–2006 and included a total of 40,322 ratings by 4,844 survey respondents for 84 unique vendors. Data for 2003 included 12,612 ratings from 1,500 respondents; 2004 included 10,553 ratings from 1,186 respondents; 2005 included 7,725 ratings from 895 respondents; and 2006 included 9,442 ratings from 1,263 respondents. The data from 16 vendors (4,028 ratings) were dropped because they could not be matched with Compustat data. This resulted in a final data set comprising 36,294 ratings. When aggregated to the vendor level by year, this resulted in a data set that has 176 observations (vendor/year) across 68 unique vendors. An average of 212 customer ratings was utilized to generate each of the aggregated vendor/year ratings. Summary statistics for the data at the buyer and vendor levels are depicted in Tables 1 and 2, respectively.

sec.p: Of the respondents, 60.1% were the top IT executives in their company, and 45.7% were C-level executives. In addition, 72% reported being very knowledgeable of IT vendor relationships, 24.5% indicated being knowledgeable, while the remaining indicated they were at least somewhat knowledgeable. Overall, the sample included companies from a variety of industries, and the respondents were likely to have the required understanding of their firms’ satisfaction with and loyalty to IT vendors.

sec.title: Buyer Level
sec.p:
The analyses involved several stages to examine relationships at separate levels. First, we conducted analyses at the level of the buyer (i). As each buyer rated multiple vendors ( j ), we included fixed effects associated with the buyers (β0i ). Fixed effects are used here because the unmeasured buyer-specific characteristics are likely to be correlated with our explanatory variables. Hausman tests confirmed that the fixed effects model was superior to the random effects model in our empirical context (see Table 3 for details). Since the loyalty measure is a binary variable, we ran logistical regression with fixed effects (Equations 2 and 3 presented below). For the equations estimating the values for the dependent variables satisfaction and loyalty, measures for whether the buyer’s relationship with the vendor involved software (s), services (r), two layers of the stack (l2), or three layers of the stack (l3) were included, as were general vendor characteristics (V) including the number of ratings, sales, and number of employees. Variables for hardware and one layer of the stack were omitted so that the equations were not overspecified, and each provides a basis for comparison when interpreting the empirical results. sec.title: Vendor Level
sec.p: Second, we conducted the analysis separately at the firm level using aggregated measures. Survey responses were aggregated by vendor (j) for each year (t) for the responses from each respondent (i) related to satisfaction, loyalty, stack level, and associated control variables. For example, the vendor level satisfaction (SAT) for a particular year was calculated as: 4 SATjt=∑1njsatijtnjt

The vendor level model included aggregated values representing the percentage of buyers that had adopted software (S), services (R), two layers of the stack (L2), and three layers of the stack (L3) and general vendor characteristics (V) including the number of ratings, sales, and employees. In addition, the aggregated controls (C) associated with the respondent profile included year (3), industry (19), job title (4), number of employees (5), and whether the respondent was a top IT executive (1). Like the buyer level analysis, the vendor level analysis includes three models, capturing the role of satisfaction in mediating the relationship between the IT stack and loyalty, as shown below: 5 SATjt=β0+β1Sjt+β2Rjt+β3L2jt+β4L3jt+β5−7Vjt+β8−39Cjt+ϵjt

We ran ordinary least squares regression with standard errors clustered by firm for satisfaction (Equation 5) and for loyalty (Equations 6 and 7). This procedure adjusts the standard error to account for firms appearing multiple times in the sample.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Results of the analyses at the level of the buyer are shown in Table 3 and analyses at the vendor level are shown in Table 4. Indicators for hardware and for a single layer of the stack are omitted, providing a baseline for the analyses of the other included variables. For the buyer level analysis of the direct effect of technology characteristics on satisfaction, coefficients for software and services are both negative, indicating significant differences between software and services from the hardware layer ( p < .001). In addition, an F-test confirmed a statistically significant difference between the coefficients for software and services ( p < .001). The aggregated vendor level model exhibits similar findings; both software ( p < .01) and services ( p < .001) coefficients are negative and significantly lower than the coefficient for the hardware layer. The F-test at the vendor level further confirmed a difference between the average satisfaction for software and services layers ( p < .01). Thus, the buyer and vendor level findings indicate that satisfaction at different stack levels follows the expected pattern, supporting Hypotheses 1a and 1b.

sec.p: Findings for the role of solutions in influencing satisfaction indicated a positive and significant coefficient at the buyer ( p < .001) and vendor levels ( p < .05), as customers obtaining solutions were relatively more satisfied than customers obtaining an individual layer of the stack (supporting both Hypotheses 2a and 2b). Supporting both Hypotheses 3a and 3b, the role of solutions in influencing loyalty also indicated a positive and significant coefficient at the buyer ( p < .001) and the vendor ( p < .05) levels when controlling for satisfaction. While not specifically hypothesized, we found that the relationship between the layers of the IT stack and loyalty was nearly completely mediated by satisfaction, with only services at the vendor level exhibiting less loyalty than hardware (p < .05) when controlling for satisfaction. Also, while the buyer level analysis indicates that bundling of two layers together leads to higher levels of satisfaction, this relationship was not significant at the vendor level.

sec.title: Robustness Checks
sec.p: To further explore the nature of the data and the robustness of the hypothesized and associated relationships, we also conducted robustness checks and post hoc analyses involving aggregated data and seemingly unrelated regression (SUR).

sec.title: Aggregated Data
sec.p: We further analyzed the mean levels of satisfaction and loyalty for each combination of hardware, software, and services to ensure that the values corresponded with our findings. The results are presented in Table 5. Satisfaction and loyalty are highest when buyers obtain hardware, software, and services together (i.e., as a solution) and lowest when they obtain only services. Mean levels of satisfaction and loyalty are also decreasing for hardware, software, and services. In addition, we find that while there are respondents with each combination of stack layers, layers that are adjacent (hardware/software; software/services) occur more frequently than layers that are not adjacent (hardware/service). These findings support hardware, software, and services—organized in a stack—as a relevant characterization of IT in the context of a vendor-buyer relationship and follow the intuition suggested by the findings from the main empirical analyses.

sec.title: SUR
sec.p: In contexts in which the error terms of a series of independent regression analyses are correlated, SUR model is suggested as an appropriate modeling technique. As our two dependent variables (satisfaction and loyalty) are correlated, it is likely that the error terms of Equations 5 and 6 will be correlated. Thus, as a robustness test, we ran the models at the vendor level using SUR. The results from the vendor level SUR analysis, shown in Table 6, are consistent with our main results in Table 4, with stronger significance levels. The buyer level analysis utilized a binary variable for loyalty, which is incompatible with SUR. While we were unable to run SUR as a robustness check at the buyer level, the binary nature of the data suggests that correlations in the error term in the system of equations are likely to be smaller at the buyer level than at the vendor level.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Overall, we find support for a model in which the type of IT provided in the context of a vendor-buyer relationship influences the resulting level of satisfaction and loyalty of IT buyers in a B2B context. Lower levels of the stack exhibited greater satisfaction than higher levels, and buyers obtaining solutions exhibited both greater satisfaction and loyalty. We discuss the theoretical and practical implications along with the conclusions drawn from this work.

sec.title: Theoretical Implications
sec.p: The study contributes to the cumulative knowledge in the area of IT product/service portfolio management. Specifically, firms providing solutions of hardware, software, and services may obtain benefits resulting from the complementarities associated with the multiple layers of the stack. We identify two mechanisms through which investing in hierarchically related technology products and services are likely to benefit vendors. First, obtaining a solution of products and services increases the overall satisfaction of customers, suggesting that complementarities of the related vendor offerings provide benefits to customers. While benefits to related diversification have typically focused on economies of scope obtained by the vendor (Tanriverdi 2005, 2006; Tanriverdi and Venkatraman 2005), our findings suggest that improved relationships and reputational benefits resulting from more satisfied customers may be the primary mechanism through which firm performance is influenced.

Second, we find that vendors offering IT solutions may also benefit from increased customer loyalty. Firms that are able to utilize IT in a way that increases switching costs are likely to be able to obtain increased profits over time, as markets for such products and services experience less price pressures in later stages of competition (Klemperer 1987). When firms offer IT solutions, they typically involve specific assets (hardware), business logic (software), and relational knowledge (services), meaning that the overall impact of switching solutions providers is quite high. Thus, strategies involving solutions are likely to improve vendor performance through both the influence on satisfaction and the influence on loyalty.

Another important contribution of our study is explicitly conceptualizing the IT artifact using the stack and considering the different elements of the IT artifact in our theorizing. Past research in the IT literature has struggled with the limited conceptualization of the technology component of IT, or the IT artifact, as researchers most frequently examined IT through related perceptions, extent of assimilation, or investments (Benbasat and Zmud 2003; Orlikowski and Iacono 2001). The type of IT obtained in the context of a vendor-buyer relationship—as examined in this research—provides a lens through which to view different technologies, as differences in the relationships provide natural boundaries to characterize different artifacts. While past research has identified differences between products and services, this research identifies software as a unique layer between hardware (which has the characteristics of a traditional product) and services. By examining how both the type of IT provided and bundling into solutions influences associated relationship outcomes of satisfaction and loyalty, we are able to provide direct insights into how design decisions related to the IT artifact influence important customer outcomes.

sec.title: Practical Implications
sec.p: As illustrated in the strategic choices made during his time at Apple, Steve Jobs’ product-focused strategy integrated hardware, software, and services offerings to provide a premium user experience. This product strategy has created tremendous value both for customers and for shareholders, developing loyal customers and making Apple the most admired company in the world 5 years in a row (CNNMoney 2012).

Among other providers of complex technologies, there is a recent trend to offer hierarchically integrated solutions, indicating that these firms believe there to be value in imitating Apple’s strategy. For example, Google’s acquisition of Motorola Mobility is largely seen as a move to enable Google to pursue a similar strategy using the Android platform as a software foundation (Efrati and Ante 2011). Google now has integrated offerings of hardware, software, and services across phones (i.e., the Nexus; Paczkowski 2012), tablets (i.e., the Nexus 7; Mossberg 2012a), and computing devices (i.e., the Chrome OS; Mossberg 2012b). Similarly, Oracle’s CEO Larry Ellison has identified Oracle’s strategy, “ … to take a lot of separate pieces that our customers used to buy as components … and do pre-integration, and deliver a complete working system” (Oracle 2010). Even Microsoft, which dominated the PC industry by focusing only on software (Liebowitz and Margolis 1999), incorporated the entire stack when launching the Surface Tablet (Ovide 2012). While future plans at Microsoft are not clear, Alesh Houdek of the Atlantic argued that “with the success of Apple’s integrated approach, and the troubles in the PC market, it seems like the time has come” for Microsoft to directly start making computers (Houdek 2012). Overall, current strategies of leading technology firms strongly support the findings presented here.

An important practical implication for IT firms is that they should consider expanding their portfolios to include products or services from adjacent layers of the stack. This is especially true for IT service vendors, as lower levels of the stack (hardware and software) exhibit greater satisfaction than higher levels (services). While past research has focused on mergers, acquisitions, and partnerships as a route to service provision (Gao and Iyer 2006, 2008), vendors can offer product bundles and solutions in other ways. Increases in modularity among product components enable firms to source complementary components (Parmigiani and Mitchell 2009), with vendors becoming solution providers by playing the role of systems integrator (Hobday, Davies, and Prencipe 2005; Prencipe, Davies, and Hobday 2005). Open source software (i.e., Linux, Moodle, and Sugar CRM) and new cloud-based models of application hosting and delivery (i.e., Amazon Web Services, RackSpace) dramatically increase the capabilities of IT vendors to deliver IT application solutions that are scalable and highly reliable. Vendors can now place a standardized machine image on Amazon, initiate new service instances, and provide support for customers looking to purchase solutions. Thus, open source software and cloud computing can enable vendors to provide solutions using systems integration capabilities that do not require the capital associated with an acquisition.

An additional practical implication of this work is that IT buyers should consider opportunities to purchase solutions. While companies specializing in single stack layers may appear favorable in side-by-side evaluations, this research suggests that buyers may be more satisfied when purchasing solutions from IT vendors. Moreover, buyers should look for deep relationships with a smaller number of IT solution providers. This aligns with prior recommendations on supplier management that suggests that IT should drive organizations toward deeper relationships with fewer suppliers (Bakos and Brynjolfsson 1993).

sec.title: Limitations and Future Work
sec.p: The data and analysis have several limitations. First, while our analyses indicate significant differences related to the stack-based classifications of hardware, software, and services, the data are limited regarding detailed information about the type of product or service obtained. For example, we are unable to identify the degree to which hardware or software has been customized to meet the specific needs of a customer. Similarly, enterprise software may differ from both personal productivity software and other applications. These differences may have implications for the overall user experience and related buyer outcomes. Future work should attempt to examine how specific IT product differences influence associated satisfaction and loyalty outcomes.

A second limitation is that we were unable to directly examine the mediating processes through which the IT vendor offerings influence satisfaction. However, as this research directly extends prior findings identifying distinctions between products and services, much of these findings provide a direct baseline on which to build an understanding of outcomes in the IT context. Future research, however, should further develop the role of uncertainty and participation throughout the presales and postsales process for more insights into the mechanisms surrounding satisfaction and loyalty in the context of IT vendor-buyer relationships.

Third, while the findings indicate an association between bundling of IT products and services and satisfaction from the perspective of the IT client, less is known regarding the long-term performance implications for the client firms. While the IT buyer satisfaction and loyalty may be higher because of reduced uncertainty and increased switching costs, solutions may have unintended consequences unlikely to be considered in the evaluation of the vendor. For example, solutions may result in a reduction in infrastructure flexibility and internal knowledge regarding IT, impacting long-term performance of the client. Thus, future work should examine the impact of IT acquisition strategy on overall buyer performance.

Finally, we were unable to identify the response rate for the sample, as this information was not available from the organization responsible for the data collection. While this could introduce the possibility of selection bias, individuals were not asked about specific vendors until beginning the survey.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The coordination and purchase of IT from vendors is a complex and challenging organizational process. In this research, we examine how the nature of vendors’ offerings—that is, hardware, software, and services—as well as the bundle of products obtained influence the resulting levels of satisfaction and loyalty. The IT products-services stack provides a way to both visualize and communicate important technology differences within the context of the vendor relationship. Findings indicate clear distinctions between hardware, software, and services in influencing vendor satisfaction ratings. In addition, our work shows that customers obtaining an integrated solution of hardware, software, and services have higher levels of satisfaction and loyalty. Thus, this work expands prior work examining product/services portfolio management and further indicates that trends toward provision of solutions positively influence customer outcomes.
